0: Finally conceding defeat to New Hampshire in the Republican calendar stare-down, Nevada’s GOP on Saturday voted to move its caucus date from Jan. 14 to Feb. 4. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR New Hampshire Secretary of State Bill Gardner is now expected to set his state’s first-in-the-nation primary for Jan. 10. He will not make any announcement before Monday, his office said Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Text Size - NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR + NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR reset POLITICO 44 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Nevada GOP’s much-anticipated move, formalized at the party’s Central Committee meeting in Las Vegas, came after 10 days of prodding from the Republican National Committee, presidential campaigns and the New Hampshire political establishment. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We want to make sure that Nevada’s voice is strong,” Nevada GOP Chairwoman Amy Tarkanian said of the move, according to the Las Vegas Review-Journal. “This has become a distraction. It’s time to move forward. … We will be the good guys in the end. We don’t need to be New Hampshire’s pinata.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “This change ensures that Nevada retains its prominent national role, as the first contest in the West and it restores Nevada’s full slate of delegates to the Republican National Convention,” RNC Chairman Reince Priebus said in a statement. “With this decision Nevada will receive the attention it deserves, and the national spotlight will focus clearly on the devastating effects that President Obama’s economic policies have had on the Silver State.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Awarded one of four coveted early-state slots by the Republican and Democratic national committees, Nevada Republicans sought to maximize their influence in the presidential nominating contest by legally changing their bylaws to tether the date of their caucus to the Saturday after New Hampshire’s primary. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But Gardner, the custodian of the New Hampshire primary since 1976, refused to play ball, declining even to speak with Tarkanian. Citing state law that requires at least seven days between his primary and the next “similar election,” Gardner vowed to wait Nevada out. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR When the Nevada state GOP could wait no longer, party leaders – who favored a Feb. 4 date, but were overrun by donors and grass-roots activists who wanted to stay ahead of Florida’s Jan. 31 primary – announced Oct. 5 that caucuses would be held Jan. 14. is date economic wait the Awarded said by to by Hampshire Democratic Democratic their make receive the that its to to with
